repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Urban Environmental Sanitation
            Project, Village Infrastructure Project, and Second
            Community Water and Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings were as follows: The Ghana Urban
            Environmental Sanitation Project had a satisfactory outcome,
            unlikely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impact; the Village Infrastructure Project had a
            satisfactory outcome, likely sustainability, and high
            institutional development impact; and the Second Community
            Water and Sanitation Project had a highly satisfactory
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impact. The Bank's and
            Borrower's performances were satisfactory for all three
            projects. Three lessons were cited: 1) Decentralization
            requires an enabling institutional environment including: a
            long term commitment, a demand-driven approach including
            beneficiary contributions, clear institutional roles and
            guidance for all stakeholders, and a common implementation
            modality for all actors. 2) A major drive to build
            implementation capacity is essential including: major
            training for local governments, communities and private
            sector support services, emphasis on up-front capacity
            building before investment in infrastructure, strong central
            coordination including monitoring and evaluation, and
            integration of hygiene education alongside the investment
            program; and 3)  Sustainability needs to be a central focus
            including: priority on raising revenues for operations and
            maintenance, institutional adjustments to improve revenue
            collection, self-sustaining support services from the
            private sector, and follow-on training for the local
            governments and community organizations.

            COASTAL MANAGEMENT,TF037768-GHANA - COMMUNITY WATER II PROJECT,TF037779-GHANA - COMMUNITY WATER II,TF037850-GHANA - COMMUNITY WATER II

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was unlikely, the institutional development impact was
            modest, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory,. The lessons learned indicate that capacity
            building for urban environmental management should be broad
            enough to include strengthening capabilities in planning,
            budgeting and revenue collection and include all related
            departments of the Metropolitan/Municipal Assemblies (Mas)
            and the decision makers. Project budgets should be allocated
            - at least partially -- on the basis of Operations and
            Maintenance (O&M) performance in order to provide an
            incentive for the local implementing agencies. The Ministry
            of Local Government and Rural Development should be more
            pro-active in providing institutional development support to
            the MAs. Addressing environmental health requires a
            cross-sectoral approach. Decentralization is a crosscutting
            theme that involves several sectors and coordination with
            work on improving the macro and governance. At the same time
            it should be recognized that the urban sector is a key
            player in that group.

5077207.owner: 8841,AFT:  Urban/Water Francophone (AFTU2),Env., NRM, WRM & DRM Prac 2 (AFTN2)
5077207.majtheme: Urban development,Environment and natural resource management

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Urban
            Environmental Sanitation Project are: 1) to promote
            productivity and raise living standards in Ghana's
            major cities, especially for lower-income people, by
            improving drainage, sanitation, and solid waste services; 2)
            to help establish better institutional and financing
            mechanisms and more effective policy frameworks so that
            improvements are sustained overtime; and 3) to build up the
            capacity of the Metropolitan and Municipal Assemblies to
            manage environmental sanitation services. The project will
            cover Ghana's five major cities: Accra, Kumasi,
            Sekondi-Takoradi, Tema, and Tamale. It will have five main
            components: 1) storm drainage; 2) sanitation; 3) solid
            waste; 4) upgrading of low-income urban areas; and 5) capacity-building.
